characters: AND MAKE MY WARS ON YOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blade of a knife. Pulled from its sheath, intricate tribal etchings on the blade catching the light. The blade being pulled across a sharpening stone. Swoosh- swoosh-swoosh. Rhythmic. A well-practiced hand. A muscula tattooed arm. The blade held up. Razor sharp. The glow of a TV in the darkened room is the only illumination. We see images on the TV: GLOBAL AND URBAN STRIFE slums barricades poverty starvation demonstrations repression refugee camps barbed wire prisons riot police tear gas violence... Then the images settle to now, BREAKING NEWS: FOOD RIOTS IN ROME. Images of a protest march. A crowd filling the streets. Soldiers moving into position. We se placards: "DOGS MUST EAT," "MEAT WAS MADE FOR MOUTHS." The man sharpening the knife watches the images. His eyes cold. Almost disinterested. Then he stops. Frozen in mid-stroke. Something on the TV suddenly rivets him. His eyes no longer cold. The TV shows one of the soldiers, a high-ranking officer. Imperious. Giving orders. We will come to know this is a as Caius Martius -- Coriolanus. TULLUS AUFIDIUS, the man sharpening the knife, gazes at t image on the screen. He leans forward. Emerging from the darkness. We see his face. He is a handsome and imposing figure, magnetic in his personality. Charismatic, yes, but also neurotic and edgy Uncomfortable in his own skin. Some demons there. He watches the face of Caius Martius on the TV screen.

Then he puts the point of his knife against the screen. Against Caius Martius' heart. Holds it there Presses the point against the screen Muscles knotting in his forearm As if he could thrust the knife through the screen and into the heart of Caius Martius... His nemesis His dark angel. Sharp cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move with an intense woman down the street. She is nervous. Checks she is not being followed. She is TAMORA, an extreme figure on the political landsca To the Roman elite she is a dangerous anarchist -- to her supporters she is an ardent patriot and democrat. As she moves, we take in Rome. It might be Mexico City. Or Chechnia. Or El Salvador. Or Detroit. Or Baghdad. Or London. This Rome is a modern place. It is our world right now: immediately recognizable to us. Elements of classical architecture loom over decay. Monolithic modernism and br public monuments are lost in a sea of brazen advertising billboards, neon shopping plazas and drab super-highways. Splendor and squalor sit side-by-side. It is a volatile, dangerous world. William Shakespeare's Rome. She comes to a graffiti-covered apartment building. Looks around. Enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A secret political meeting in a police state. Tension. Cigarette smoke hangs in the air. Men and women gathered, hushed and urgent tones. A cell meeting of the political opposition, the resistance. A TV shows the food marches elsewhere in the city. The gathering storm. CASSIUS is a leading proletariat organizer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak -- You are all resolved rather to die than to famish? The others agree. They are not wild-eyed radicals. They a normal people, from all walks of life. You and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, you know Caius Martius is chief enemy to the people. A voice from the back of the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us kill him. The others turn. Tamora, just entering, pulls off her coa joins the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll have corn at our own price. Is it a verdict? Some are unsure. She is too extreme for some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good The leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, our sufferance, is a gain to them. Let us revenge this with our sticks ere we become rakes! I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge. A woman, a YOUNG MOTHER, protests:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you proceed especially against Caius Martius?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against him first. A COLLEGE PROFESSOR, speaks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, and could be content to give

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: him good report for it -- but that he pays himself with being proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, but speak not maliciously. She has over-played her hand. Pretends to back down:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did it to that end... (a snarky smile) He did it to please his mother. Some laugh at her gossip. Then the TV image switches to a BREAKING NEWS update: From the Roman Senate. An august press room. A Senator is moving to a podium to make a statement. He is Senator MENENIUS is a seasoned and wily politician. Silver hair, perfectly tailored suit. He is known as a fo "man of the people." It is a role he plays to perfection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft, who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worthy Senator Menenius, one that hath always loved the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one honest enough; would all the rest were so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbors, Will you undo yourselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, friends, most charitable care Have the patricians of you, For your wants, Your suffering in this dearth, you may as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike at the heavens with your staves as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against the Roman state--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking to the TV) Suffer us to famish, and their storehouses crammed with grain-- The others shush her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alack, you are transported by calamity Thither where more attends you; and you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helms of the state, who care for you like fathers, When you curse them as enemies-- Cassius mutes the TV. We see Senator Menenius continuing his speech; his attempt to calm the dangerous situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care for us? They never cared for us yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the wars eat us not up, they will: and that's all the love they bear us. The others are growing increasingly restive -- shifting -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why stay we prating here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more talking on it! To the Capitol! Come! Come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamora, Cassius and the others are now in the midst of th protest march. The crowd has become a mob, with a life an will of its own. The crowd surges forward-- They round a corner and suddenly stop-- For a formidable sight awaits them- RIOT POLICE. Rows of black uniforms. Full riot gear with plexiglass shields and dangerous truncheons.

A few soldiers on horses as well. The crowd starts and shifts nervously, unsure how to proc Should they launch themselves against this monolithic military force? A long, tense beat. Then... One of the horsemen trots forward... He rides a beautiful white horse... It is CAIUS MARTIUS. (Soon to be given the honorary title Coriolanus.) He is intense and patrician. Uncompromising. man of steel. A soldier. He wears a crisp, military unifo From his position on the horse, Martius looks over the rioters... His gaze is ice... A long beat... Then he dismounts... He slowly walks to the unruly mob... With no hesitation, unarmed... He stops before them... And speaks with absolute disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, you dissentious rogues, That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, Make yourselves scabs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have ever your good word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He that will give good words to thee will

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath abhorring. The crowd is hushed. Taking in his every word.
We note a TV news crew has moved into position and is fil eagerly. Some in the crowd film with cell phone cameras. Streaming video. We intercut some of these perspectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you have, you curs? He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where foxes, geese. He walks along the front of the crowd. Some are frightene the great Martius. Some are even awed. Others glare at hi with loathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate... Hang ye! Trust ye? With every minute you do change your mind, And call him noble that was now your hate, Him vile that was your garland. He continues along the crowd, his cold eyes taking in fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, That in these several places of the city You cry against the noble Senate, who, Under the gods, keep you in awe, which

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would feed on one another? He stops and glares at the mob with seething anger. He climbs back onto his horse. Stares down at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go GET YOU HOME, YOU FRAGMENTS! A tense beat. The riot police shift nervously. The crowd is unsure. The TV news crew films everything.

Cassius looks around. He sees the police ready with tear He sees old men, women and children in his crowd. He does want this to explode. He exchanges a few whispers works with Tamora. Word is pa and the crowd begins to disperse. Some run off in a panic Others walk away. The danger has passed. Senator Menenius, who has been watching from nearby, gest for Martius to join him. He is an old family friend of Martius' as well as his mentor and chief political adviso Menenius is relieved bloodshed has been avoided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are almost thoroughly persuaded; For though abundantly they lack discretion, Yet are they passing cowardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are dissolved. Hang 'em. Senator Menenius watches the crowd. Disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would they were abed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would they were in Tiber. They move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the TV image of Martius railing at the people from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go GET YOU HOME, YOU FRAGMENTS! Tullus Aufidius is leaning in. Watching so closely. From his POV: the pixilated close-up of Martius' face on screen. He runs his knife blade back and forth. Turns it in the light; the reflection of Martius' face distorting as he rotates the blade.
Then Aufidius leans back again. Back into the shadows. Disappearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rome's military headquarters. A high security building li the Pentagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius is seated with several MILITARY OFFICERS and AIDE Also with him is TITUS. He younger than Martius, an old friend and comrade-in-arms. Like Martius he has seen a lo battle. COMINIUS, an older general, enters. He is an experienced commander of men also used to dealing with the necessary politics of civilian oversight. West Point bearing. All salute. Cominius returns the salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news is the Volsces are in arms. An aide presses a remote. Grainy video images play on a monitor: Volscian soldiers, jeeps, tanks. One section shows a quick image of the rebel leader, a striking man called Tullus Aufidius, riding past in a jee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a leader, Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sin in envying his nobility, And were I any thing but what I am, I would wish me only he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have fought together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a lion That I am proud to hunt. Martius takes the remote control. Stops the video. Rewind the unclear image of Aufidius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Titus Lartius, thou Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead you on. Martius rewinds and plays the image of Aufidius again, rewinds and plays it again, almost obsessively. We push in on the video image of Aufidius... Aufidius appears to be staring right back at Martius... And this takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same face. Aufidius, who is the leader of the rebel Volscian forces, stands deep in thought. The Volsces are an insurgent force challenging the monoli might of Rome: rebels that suggest to us Latin American revolutionaries or Hamas fighters or Chechnian separatist They are a dangerous guerilla force. We are in the Volsce war room in an old apartment buildin basement. No windows. Secure. OFFICERS and some civilian POLITICIANS. The room is fille with military maps, weapons, surveillance photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, your opinion is, Aufidius, That they of Rome are entered in our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And know how we proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it not yours? Tis not four days gone since I heard thence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never yet made doubt but Rome was

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To answer us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is rumored Martius, your old enemy, leads in their preparation. He tosses a glossy magazine on the desk, a picture of Mar on the cover. Aufidius' eyes spark at the image of Martius. He picks up the magazine and carefully tears off the cove picture of Martius, looking at the picture deeply. He continues with a strange and grim fire:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we and Caius Martius chance to meet, 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till one can do no more. By the elements, If ever again I meet him beard to beard, He's mine or I am his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful butterfly. Catching the light perfectly, almo iridescent. It floats before a palatial mansion in the suburbs of the great city. Manicured lawns. Formal gardens. Classical architectural lines. This fine home of aristocratic privilege seems a world aw from the urban blight of Rome. In the immaculate front gardens YOUNG MARTIUS, Martius' s is playing. The boy is about ten. There is something grim lonely about him, without charm. Young Martius chases after the butterfly, trying to catch He fails. The butterfly flits away. Young Martius leaps a it. Again he misses. Finally the frustrated boy manages to catch the butterfly his rage he tears it to pieces, brutally shredding it. We realize he is being observed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . VIRGILIA, Martius' wife, stands at the window. Disturbe by the sight of her son ripping apart the butterfly.

She sees Young Martius stop and look at the tiny bit of b on his fingers. Young Martius is unmoved. He glances up. Locks eyes with his mother. She turns away. Virgilia was well-chosen for her role as wife to one of Rome's most aristocratic men. She is beautiful and gracef but -- like Diana thrown into lion's den of the Windsor family -- woefully out of her depth. We feel an inner fragility to her. The room is spacious and elegantly appointed. A lovely Ro statue in one corner. This is a place of wealth, order an control. A fine flat-screen TV flickers with images of war. We see helicopters zooming over desert landscape Imbedded war correspondents Tanks Combat Romans . Volscians. VOLUMNIA, Martius' mother, stands and watches the TV. She an imposing woman, handsome and tall, impeccably dressed. Adamantine in her strength. Virgilia moves from the window. Sits on a sofa. She watch the TV news footage of the war, upset by the images. A frozen silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a more comfortable sort. If my son were my husband, I should more freely rejoice in that absence wherein he won honor than in the embracements of his bed where he would show most love. She moves across the room to fetch a cigarette. She moves always, with stately grace. She walks past a series of photographs. They tell the sto of Martius' life: the happy baby; the stern dead father; rigid young military cadet; the formal wedding; the restrained and unsmiling adult. In the photos we sense a transformation: innocent boy to experienced, severe looking soldier. Volumnia is present most of the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When yet he was but tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, I, considering how honor would become such a person, was pleased to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame. She lights her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he returned, his brows bound with oak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But had he died in the business, madam, how then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then his good report should have been my son. (she rivets Virgilia) Had I a dozen sons I had rather have eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action. A MAID enters. She speaks to Volumnia (the true mistress the house) not to Virgilia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, Senator Menenius is come to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Menenius we are fit to bid him welcome. The Maid goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, you shall not! She turns off the TV and goes to a bar to mix drinks. She mixes the drinks aggressively, strangely inspired by the discussion of war:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Methinks I hear hither your husband's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Come on, you cowards! You were got in fear, Though you were born in Rome." His bloody

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then wiping, forth he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His bloody brow? 0 Jupiter, no blood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away, you fool! It more becomes a man Than gold his trophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavens bless my lord from fell Auf idius ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll beat Aufidius' head below his knee And tread upon his neck. Senator Menenius enters, he is comfortable in this house an old ally of Volumnia's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ladies both, good day to you. Volumnia hands him one of the drinks she has been mixing: perfect martini. She knows how he takes his drink. She is above flirting with him when it suits her ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how does your little son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thank you, sir; well, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had rather play with swords and hear a drum than look upon his schoolmaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my word, the father's son! He and Volumnia laugh. Menenius has sensed Virgilia's tension. Tries to cheer he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, I must have you play the idle housewife with me this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, good sir, I will not out of doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not out of doors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shall, she shall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, no, by your patience. I'll not over the threshold till my lord return from the wars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot go hither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would be another Penelope; yet they say all the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, good sir, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go with me and I'll tell you excellent news of your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, good sir, there can be none yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There came news from him last night. Volumnia pounces, moving in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your lord and Titus Lartius are set down before the Volscian city of Corioles. They nothing doubt prevailing and to make it brief wars This is true, on mine honor; and so, I pray, go out with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me excuse, good sir. I will obey you in everything hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her alone. As she is now, she will but disease our better mirth. She takes Menenius arm and pulls him out, eager for more of her son. Virgilia sits for a beat. Then she presses a button on the remote control. The TV g on again. More news reports of the war. We see images of the Volscian town of Corioles. A "BREAKI NEWS" scroll runs across the bottom of the screen The Battle for Corioles Virgilia watches the war footage, her eyes haunted. Hard cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! A series of explosions jolt us. Corioles is a small urban center. Smoke billows up from a of the city. The steady crack and rattle of gunfire. The occasional thud of explosions. We see urban street-to-street fighting. The images are startling in their familiarity: this could be Basra or Belfast. The battle is photographed in a gritty exposure. Color is drained out -- blood is a darker red like oil. Soldiers a dark forms moving through shadows and smoke. Martius and Titus, leading a platoon of around twenty Rom SOLDIERS, run into view and take cover. Bullets zip and s around them. The Roman soldiers wear modern battle fatigues and body armor, tricked out with all the latest tech gear. The Volscians, being a poor guerilla force, wear thrown toget uniforms that look almost tribal. Martius calls over the incessant din of battle to Titus a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fear us not, but issue forth their city. Sniper bullets slam into a wall near him. He coughs away smoke and debris. This only makes him more angry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts, Which makes me sweat with wrath! He that retires, I'll take him for a Volsce, And he shall feel mine edge! Martius leaps up and races on. The others follow in milit order. The Roman soldiers move along the street -- it is chaotic explosions, smoke and sniper fire -- they duck into doorw and behind abandoned cars -- returning fire as best they Martius leads -- firing stead bursts from his machine gun It is slow and bloody going-- Finally the Romans turn a corner and are stopped by a roadblock: a burning bus that fills the entire street-- The Volsces use this roadblock to ambush the Roman soldie We see glimpses of Volscian soldiers darting for position firing from rooftops and from inside shops--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius runs into a blasted hotel room. Some of his sold with him. He goes to the window. Scans the street below. Sees Marti and the others trapped at the bus. He gestures to an aide

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the face of the crossfire, the Roman soldiers start

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius refuses to yield -- pushing and shoving his men toward the burning bus -- screaming in fury over the nois

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You souls of geese, That bear the shapes of men! PLUTO AND

dialogues.speaker: HELL
dialogues.text: All hurt behind! Backs red, and faces

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home, Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave

dialogues.speaker: AND MAKE MY WARS ON YOU
dialogues.text: An EXPLOSION -- dirt and brick shards slash across Martiu face -- blood-- This only pushes his fury to white rage--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look to it. Come on!

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW ME
dialogues.text: He leaves his soldiers behind-- Moves alone to the burning bus and fights his way through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius is in his own world now. He doesn't even realize is alone. He has become a sort of killing machine. A shar moving through the ocean. Ruthless and efficient. We become the warrior. From Martius' POV: We move through disorienting curtains of smoke... Continue down the street... Firing a heavy machine gun... Volscian soldiers contort and die, torn to pieces by the bullets... The heavy machine gun is empty, we drop it and use a side firing strategic shots... Volscian soldiers dart up -- fire -- and die... We keep moving steadily forward... Shadowy shapes moving nearby, we fire. Killing civilians. fortunes of war...

Strange surreal images. We smash into a house. An OLD MAN crouches, terrified, in a corner. He reaches forward. He offering us water. An act of kindness amid the carnage... We move on... Panicked civilians, scattering in terror... Volscian soldiers rush us, attacking, we slam them aside. We duck down, roll under a car, emerge and fire... More Volscians die... We continue forward... Then the pistol is empty, we drop it and pull a machete-l knife... Still moving relentlessly forward... Slashing and killing... Hand-to-hand now... Carnage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius and his aides are racing down an alley, trying t get to Martius-- Roman fire stops them-- They return fire as they divert down another alley, tryin for a better strategic position, running flat out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Titus and the soldiers are still pinned down at the burni bus. Two soldiers race back to Titus to report, they dive cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is become of Martius?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slain, sir, doubtless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is himself alone, To answer all the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou art lost, Martius... Titus has no time to mourn. He looks over the hopeless situation. Scanning the rooftops, windows and shops. Then he stops He sees something Past the burning bus Through the smoke and flames... He glimpses a ghostly figure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's yonder, That does appear as he were flayed? 0 gods! He has the stamp of Martius. It is indeed Martius. A shocking sight. Drenched head-to-toe in blood. His face splattered with gore. His eyes wild. Lost in something like rapture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come I too late?! Come I too late?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others, But mantled in your own. Martius laughs wildly and embraces Titus, who comes away splattered with blood:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, let me clip ye In arms as sound as when I wooed, in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As merry as when our nuptial day was done! SUDDENLY -- a deafening explosion -- and RPG EXPLODING fr nearby. Then gunfire. Bullets shatter windows. The Volsci are attacking again. The Romans instantly begin diving for cover and taking up

Martius scans the location. Sees the attack is coming fro old Hilton hotel. Now pockmarked with bullets and artille shells. Most of the windows shattered. This is the Volscian stronghold. The last stand. He sees flashes of Volscian soldiers moving on the roof and balconies, and snipers firing from windows. There is an open plaza, littered with bodies and debris, front of the hotel. Martius stops scanning with his binoculars-- Sees Aufidius moving in the hotel, directing the battle--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the man of my soul's hate--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piercing our Romans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worthy sir, thou bleeds. Thy exercise hath been too violent For a second course of fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, praise me not. My work hath yet not warmed me. The blood I drop is more medicinal Than dangerous to me. To Aufidius thus I will appear and fight. He turns to some soldiers, imploring them to join him. Hi bloody visage and intensity are strangely inspiring, his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If any such be here- As it were sin to doubt - that love this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherein you see me smeared; if any fear Lesser his person than an ill report; If any think brave death outweighs bad life, And that his country's dearer than

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him alone, or so many so minded, Wave thus, to express his disposition,

dialogues.speaker: AND FOLLOW MARTIUS
dialogues.text: The soldiers are pumped up -- like Marines straining for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zigzagging across the plaza toward the hotel-- Titus and the others provide covering fire--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius zigzags with his men across the dangerously expos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They return fire at the hotel as best they can, but the barrage from the Volscians is murderous-- Roman soldiers contort and fall, blood spraying-- Bullets snap and ricochet everywhere around them-- But still they keep up a steady pace, reloading and firin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Martius is hit--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But still he keeps on-- The front of the hotel is closer now-- Martius and his soldiers race to the hotel and crash into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius and his soldiers battle the Volscian defenders in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the weird and incongruous nature of modern urban warfare: soldiers fighting to the death among hotel couch and tatty corporate artwork-- It is brutal-- Martius and his soldiers cut a bloody swath across the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another HUGE EXPLOSION rocks the hotel -- like a seismic blast -- an ugly 1970's chandelier falls--
Martius and his men move into a stairwell--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius and his men race up the stairway- Volscians are firing down at them-- Bullets ricochet crazily in the confined stairway, refrac from concrete walls and twisting metal railing, sending u sparks and clouds of dust-- Then Martius slows to a stop. Looks up. Aufidius is on the stairway above. Glaring down at him. A long beat as they lock eyes. Both panting for breath in heat of the combat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hate alike. Then Martius does something astounding. He holds out his arms to his sides and drops his weapons. They clatter down. Aufidius does the same. The Roman and Volscian soldiers watch. None daring to interfere. Martius and Aufidius continue to glare at each other -- dropping weapons -- disarming -- Martius climbing up the stairs, Aufidius coming down -- moving closer and closer- At an instant- They slam together- Fighting without weapons-- Grappling brutally. Tearing at each other. Twining togeth Fingers grasping. Teeth snapping. Hands pulling. It is a bloody, terrible, graceless struggle.
They crash and slam awkwardly in the claustrophobic stairwell. Smashing into the walls. Falling from level to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another EXPLOSION rocks the hotel-- Part of the roof COLLAPSES-- Concrete SLAMS down-- A cloud of smoke, dust and debris obscures everything- Martius is tossed violently to the ground in the action-- Aufidius is pulled away by several of his men. They drag to safety. Roman soldiers fire after them. The sound is deafening in the confined garage. But Aufidius and his comrades disappear into a cloud of d Gone. Martius glares after him. Wipes blood from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hotel lobby has been turned into a hastily assembled emergency triage station. The moaning and screaming of the injured are constant. Ro medics attend to the wounded: administering IVs; arrangin evacuations; performing battlefield surgery. Martius sits, dried blood covering his face, looking over injured and dying soldiers as a medic stitches up a wound his arm. Titus is with him. General Cominius enters with several attending officers, going to congratulate Martius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I should tell thee over this thy day's work, Thou would not believe thy deeds. Martius is barely listening. His attention is on a YOUNG SOLDIER across the room. The Young Soldier is injured, pa and thirsty. Dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll report it Where Senators shall mingle tears with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where great patricians shall attend and shrug, In the end admire and say: "We thank the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Rome hath such a soldier."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray now, no more. My mother, When she does praise me, grieves me. I have done as you have done - that's what I can; Induced as you have been - that's for my country. Martius continues to look at the poor dying soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rome must know The value of her own. It were a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worse than a theft, To hide your doings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some wounds upon me, and they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hear themselves remembered. The surgeon finishes stitching Martius' arm. Starts to cl another wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should they not, Well might they fester against

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too modest are you. Impatient, Martius rises, painfully and slowly. He takes canteen and crosses to the Young Soldier. Gives his cante to the boy. The Young Soldier drinks. His deep, sad eyes up at Martius. Martius watches as... The Young Soldier dies. The light goes from his eyes. His head hangs awkwardly. His boyish face is leaden. Martius suddenly finds himself exhausted. Morally and physically spent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will go wash; And when my face is fair, you shall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether I blush or no Howbeit, thank you. Martius stares at the dead soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius and some of his Volscian soldiers, bloody and filthy, are on foot. They are moving through the outskirts of Corioles, leavin the city. Exhausted after the long and failed battle. Fires burn from blasted shops and homes. The Romans have clearly laid waste to this part of the city. There is a minivan stopped ahead of them. Bullets holes everywhere. Bodies inside. They walk to it. Aufidius looks in. A dead family. Father mother, kids in the back. Bloody toys on the floor of the minivan. Roman atrocities. Aufidius gazes at the bodies. His face hardens. He whispers to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five times, Martius, I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me, And would do so, I think, should we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As often as we eat. He becomes aware some of his men are looking at him, disturbed at his fervor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought to crush him in an equal force, True sword to sword, I'll stab him some way, Or wrath -- or craft -- may get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bolder, though not so subtle. A beat. Aufidius continues with prayer-like intensity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My valor, poisoned with him, Shall fly out of itself ... Nor sleep, nor sanctuary, being naked, Sick, the prayers of priests, Nor times of sacrifice, Shall lift up their rotten privilege And custom, Against my hate to Martius. In the shattered glass of the minivan window, Aufidius suddenly sees himself. He studies his own face, nurturing his dark thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where I find him, were it At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, Will I wash my fierce hand in his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in Rome, we are at a comfortable restaurant/bar near Senate where politicians gather to eat, drink, gossip and conspire. The business of state is conducted over steak a martinis. Comfortable red leather booths. Wooden panelling. Two Tribunes -- Senators chosen to speak for the people - are having lunch. BRUTUS is a large man in a rumpled grey suit; a sweating with a taste for bare-knuckle politics. SICINIUS is small and vulpine; crafty and cold. Both are ambitious politicos used to manipulating the peo and the press for their personal ends. With them sits Cassius, the political agitator we met before. The TV over the bar shows images of Martius' victory: parading Roman troops; Volscian prisoners; flags; adoring crowds; triumphant slogans; "Mission Accomplished."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was ever man so proud as is this Martius?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has no equal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we were chosen Tribunes for the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marked you his lip and eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, but his taunts. They see Senator Menenius approaching. Sicinius nods to Cassius, who quickly goes. Menenius stops by on his way out. He is jolly, knowing th victory will assure his protege's political future:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good or bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Martius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You blame Martius for being proud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do it not alone, sir. Subtly, the polite chit-chat is turning more serious and pointed; Menenius growing sharper. The gloves are coming

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you can do very little alone You talk of pride: 0 that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves! 0 that you could!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any in Rome. The saturnine Sicinius' response seems almost a threat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying water in it; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning. What I think I utter, and spend my malice in my breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know neither me, yourselves nor anything You are ambitious. A tense beat. They are formidable adversaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-e'en to your worships. More of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians I will be bold to take my leave of you. He goes. The Tribunes watch him cut through the lunch cro and exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Roman Senate is constructed with classical symmetry a clean, square lines. Probably the most striking and beaut building in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia, Virgilia and Menenius are hurrying down a corri excited. All are well-dressed, for an important public ev

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honorable Menenius, my boy Martius approaches! For the love of Juno, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, no, no, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, he is wounded! I thank the gods for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I too -- if it be not too much. Brings a victory in his pocket, the wounds become him. Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Titus Lartius says they fought together, but Aufidius got off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In truth, there's wondrous things spoke of him. Gods grant them true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an exhalation of scorn) True?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded? Volumnia and Menenius now gleefully add up her son's woun like accountants -- or campaign managers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the shoulder and in the left arm. There will be large scars to show the people, when he shall stand for his place He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts in the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One in the neck, and two in the thigh - there's nine that I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's twenty-seven. Every gash was an enemy's grave. We focus on Volumnia's face as she thinks about her son. VOLUMNIA BEFORE HIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears. Death, that dark spirit, in his nervy arm DOTH LIE;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die. They hurry to the stop of a grand staircase, where there people waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They join Cominius and other dignitaries at the top of a majestic stairway. An honor guard of Roman soldiers in dress uniforms are waiting. Roman flags flutter. All very ceremonial. Martius enters below. The honor guard snaps to attention. Martius -- hereafter called Coriolanus -- slowly begins t cross to the steps. We see that walking is very difficult for him. His wounds are severe and every movement is agon He has paid a steep price for his victory. Photographers flash photos and a TV crew film the ceremon Coriolanus finally reaches the steps leading up. He takes breath and slowly begins to climb the stairs, each step a challenge. Volumnia looks down on him. Unmoved by his pain. Virgilia is distraught. As Coriolanus slowly hauls himself up the last few steps, General Cominius speaks into a cluster of microphones and addresses the press:
COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be it known, As to us, to all the world, that Caius MARTIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wears this war's garland And from this time, For what he did before Corioles, call him, With all the applause and clamor of the host, "Caius Martius Coriolanus!" (TO MARTIUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bear the addition nobly ever! The soldiers salute in a grim sort of chant: SOLDIERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caius Martius Coriolanus! Coriolanus has reached the podium. An awkward beat. Comin gestures for him to speak into the microphones. He tersely does so: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more of this; it does offend my heart. Pray now, no more. An awkward silence. Cominius elegantly tries to covers th MOMENT: COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, sir, your mother. CORIOLANUS
You have, I know, petitioned all the gods For my prosperity. He kneels to her -- slowly, with great difficulty -- she him. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, my good soldier, up. (he slowly rises) My gentle Martius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honor newly named - What is it? - Coriolanus must I call thee? She laughs coquettishly, thoroughly upstaging her son. Then, almost an afterthought:
VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, 0, thy wife... Coriolanus greets Virgilia with the clumsy and stiff formality that marks their marriage. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My gracious silence, hail. An awkwardly tender kiss. He notes her tears. Reacts cold CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would thou have laughed had I come coffined home, That weeps to see me triumph? Ay, my dear, Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear, And mothers that lack sons. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the gods crown thee! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (greets him warmly) And live you yet? VOLUMNIA (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know not where to turn. 0, welcome home! And welcome, general. And you're welcome all! MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred thousand welcomes! Coriolanus is surrounded by well-wishers and political admirers. Volumnia and Menenius usher him along. We see the image from TV: The noble warrior returned home Devoted family. Flags waving. The future golden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then the hard reality. Coriolanus' body is a battleground of scars. Some are liv and red, fresh and still oozing blood. Others are pale an blue, discolored and dead. His body is something monstrous. Stitched up. Patched together. Slashed around. Frankenstein's monster.

He is leaning against a sink, stripped naked. His muscula shattered body exposed. Volumnia sits and dresses her son's wounds. As she always done. As she always will. It is a disturbing, intimate image. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good Senators must be visited; From whom I have received not only greetings, But with them change of honors. He shifts painfully as she continues to treat one of his wounds. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy. Only There's one thing wanting, which I doubt NOT BUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Rome will cast upon thee. He catches her eye in the mirror, very firm: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way, Than sway with them in theirs. They stop when-- Virgilia enters. She stops in the doorway. It is embarrassing for her, as she has interrupted two lovers. A long moment. She looks to her husband. To Volumnia. They stare back. There is no way she can compete with their intimacy. Surrendering, she silently goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgilia wanders a long hallway, past a fine collection o antique Roman weaponry. She seems lost.

She stops and opens a door, glances into her son's bedroo Young Martius is asleep. Her eyes move across his room. The military toys. The lit cadet uniform carefully hung. The polished boots waiting. All stern and joyless. Not like a child's room at all. Virgilia closes the door and continues down the long hall disappearing into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkened office. Brutus and Sicinius sit, heads together, focused. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot temperately transport his honors, but will Lose those he hath won. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard him swear, Were he to stand for Consul, never would HE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appear in the marketplace nor Showing, as the manner is, his wounds To the people, beg "their stinking breaths." SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was his word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutus and Sicinius continue as they hurry to the Senate CHAMBER: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it must fall out with him, Or our authorities at an end. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must suggest to the people in what HATRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still hath held them. BRUTUS (SHUSHING HIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace...
They enter the Senate Chamber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brutus and Sicinius make their way to their seats as we h

dialogues.speaker: MENENIUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It remains, As the main point of this our after- meeting, To gratify his noble service that Hath thus stood for his country... The interior of the grand Senate is an airy, sweeping cha that suggests the Israeli Knesset or U.N. General Assembl Again, classical symmetry is the rule with tiers of seats facing a central dais. An imposing piece of outdated mode art suggesting the might of Rome looms over the chamber l a bird of prey. Network TV cameras purr quietly from a corner. Menenius, Cominius, Coriolanus and several other politico are seating at a central table on the dais, facing the ro of SENATORS. Menenius is standing at a podium, speaking into a microph MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, please you, Most reverend and grave elders, to desire The present Consul, and last general In our well-found successes, to report A little of that worthy work performed By Caius Martius Coriolanus. SENATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak, good Cominius. General Cominius rises and moves to the podium. But then Coriolanus abruptly stands-- MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, keep your place. SENATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit, Coriolanus. Never shame to hear What you have nobly done.
CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honors' pardon. I had rather have my wounds to heal again Than hear say how I got them. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray now, sit down. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had rather have one scratch my head in THE SUN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the alarum were struck than idly sit To hear my nothings monstered. Coriolanus moves across the dais and exits into a hallway The door shuts after him. Menenius sighs. Nods to Cominius. Cominius moves to the podium and begins to read his speec from a Teleprompter. This all has the rehearsed quality o campaign nomination speech. COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deeds of Coriolanus Should not be uttered feebly. It is held That valor is the chiefest virtue, and Most dignifies the haver. Alone he ENTERED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mortal gate of the city, And struck Corioles like a planet, From face to foot He was a thing of blood... Brutus and Sicinius exchange a glance, bored by the polit boilerplate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Coriolanus stands in the service corridor beyo the chamber. Green industrial walls. Ugly fluorescent lig above. He leans against a wall, alone with his thoughts. Cominius' voice can be heard droning inside. Then Coriolanus glances up. A CUSTODIAN is pushing a garb can down the long corridor. He stops when he sees Coriola Coriolanus' cool, uncompromising stare makes the Custodia uneasy. He turns around and goes back.

Coriolanus waits. His face strangely vacant. He flexes his wounded arm. It hurts. He hears Cominius finish. A good round of applause. He he his name being cheered: "Coriolanus!" Coriolanus closes his eyes, steels himself, and then re- enters the chamber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius greets him and escorts him to the podium for his "acceptance speech." MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased To make thee Consul! Menenius steps back. A beat. Coriolanus stares at the Senators. At the TV cameras. He leans awkwardly into the podium microphone: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do owe them still My life and services. A beat. For an acceptance speech, rather terse. Menenius jumps in salvage the moment: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It then remains That you do speak to the people. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do beseech you, Let me overleap that custom, for I cannot ENTREAT THEM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For my wounds' sake to give their suffrage. Please you that I may pass this doing. From the Senate floor, Sicinius jumps on this: SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the people Must have their voices!
The Senators, led by Brutus, clamor their agreement. Tradition must be obeyed. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calming, to Coriolanus) Pray you, go fit you to the custom. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a part That I shall blush in acting, and might WELL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be taken from the people. Menenius quickly turns off Coriolanus' microphone. BRUTUS (TO SICINIUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark you that? CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To brag unto them "Thus I did, and thus!" Show them the unaching scars which I should hide, As if I had received them for the hire Of their breath only! Menenius sees Coriolanus is getting angry, this could be disastrous. He elegantly gestures for Cominius to escort Coriolanus o immediately -- as he addresses the Senators and TV camera MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To our noble Consul Wish we all joy and honor! He applauds. The applause is taken up by the Senators. So cheering as well for the hero of Rome The two Tribunes, however, are already whispering maliciously to other Senators. Menenius seems pleased with the general response. So far, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia is pleased as well. She sits, watching the events unfold on TV. The sound of the cheering fades as we go to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine winds through the pedestrian traffic toward Roman marketplace. Coriolanus sits with Menenius. Coriolanus is both angry a embarrassed. He is wearing a sharp business suit. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you not known The worthiest men have done it? CORIOLANUS (AGREES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Custom calls me to it. What custom wills, in all things should we do... What must I say? "Look, sir, my wounds. I got them in my country's service." MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O me, the gods! You must not speak like that. You must DESIRE THEM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To think upon you-- CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Think upon me"? Hang 'em! I would they would forget me. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll mar all! The limo stops. They are at the marketplace. The moment h come. Menenius takes a breath. Urges calm: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray you, speak to them, I pray you, In wholesome manner. CORIOLANUS (SOURLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bid them wash their faces And keep their teeth clean. He leaves the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commercial heart of Rome. A large town square, since antiquity used as a marketplace. But now it is filled with tatty stalls selling cheap purs and knock-off watches. Paltry fruit stands alongside shab souvenir stalls. Advertising billboards surround and pollute the square -- SONY. COKE. NIKE. MCDONALDS -- obscuring any classical architecture that might have survived. Tamora and Cassius, the political activists, are in the crowd. They watch closely. Coriolanus slowly walks to the center of the marketplace. stands, feeling ridiculous and not at all humble. He looks around. Waiting for something to happen. The CUSTOMERS and SHOPKEEPERS just look back at him. Some curious. Some are amused. Some hostile and most indiffere But no one approaches. Then Coriolanus understands. He must g to them: beg for votes. He prepares himself and then slowly moves through the var stalls, weaving in and out. Trying to maintain his dignit He sees the Citizens from before and goes to them. We gli Brutus and Sicinius amongst the crowd. CORIOLANUS (TO CASSIUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the cause, sir, of my standing here. CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do, sir. Tell us what hath brought you to it. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine own desert. TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your own desert? CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, but not mine own desire.
TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How not your own desire? CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging. CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think, if we give you anything, we hope to gain by you. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, I pray, your price of the Consulship? WAR VET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The price is to ask it kindly. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kindly, sir, I pray, let me have it. I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private Your good voice, sir. What say you? WAR VET (IMPRESSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall have it, worthy sir. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged. I have your alms. Adieu. Business done, so he thinks, Coriolanus crisply moves on. Cassius is not convinced. CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is something odd. Coriolanus continues on. He sees a large JAMAICAN WOMAN w her CHILDREN, carrying plastic grocery bags, talking to a SHOPKEEPER. He goes to them: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be Consul. JAMAICAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have not deserved nobly. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your enigma?
JAMAICAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been a scourge to her enemies; you have been a rod to her friends You have not indeed loved the common people. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in my love Therefore, beseech you, I may be Consul. SHOPKEEPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hope to find you our friend, and therefore give you our voices heartily. JAMAICAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have received many wounds for your country. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no farther. JAMAICAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily! Coriolanus is warming to the task, it's easier than he thought. He moves to a central, open area and declares PUBLICLY: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your voices! For your voices I have FOUGHT;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watched for your voices; for your voices BEAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice SIX

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen and heard of! A crowd is gathering. We note Brutus and Sicinius in the crowd. Menenius, too, has moved in. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your voices Have done many things, some less, some more. Your voices! Indeed, I would be Consul. WAR VET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man's voice!

dialogues.speaker: RACE TRACK TOUT
dialogues.text: Therefore let him be Consul! JAMAICAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people! The Citizens applaud and give their support: CITIZENS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble Consul! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worthy voices! Menenius, with Brutus and Sicinius, goes to him: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have stood your limitation, and the TRIBUNES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endue you with the people's voice. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this done? SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The custom of request you have discharged. The people do admit you, and are summoned To meet anon upon your approbation. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? At the Senate? SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, Coriolanus. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll keep you company. (TO BRUTUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you along? BRUTUS (DECLINES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stay here for the people. Coriolanus and Menenius go, relieved the trial is over. Brutus and Sicinius, however, have work to do. This has n gone as they wanted. They are urgent: SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How now, my masters! Have you chose this man?
CASSIUS (RUEFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has our voices, sir. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves. TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice, He mocked us when he begged our voices. CASSIUS CERTAINLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flouted us downright. JAMAICAN WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it is his kind of speech; he did not mock us. TAMORA (SHARPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should have showed us His marks of merit, wounds received for's country. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, so he did, I am sure. TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no! No one saw them! CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inciting the crowd) Was not this mockery? Brutus presses hard: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he had no power, But was a petty servant to the state, He was your enemy, ever spake against Your liberties. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you perceive He did solicit you in free contempt When he did need your loves, and do you THINK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That his contempt shall not be bruising TO YOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he hath power to crush?
Cassius and Tamora carefully lead the crowd in expressing growing alarm and resistance to Coriolanus: CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not confirmed; we may deny him yet! TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And will deny him! I'll have five hundred voices of that sound. CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I twice five hundred and their friends! The crowd roars approval. A frightening, animal sound. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them assemble, And on a safer judgment all revoke Your ignorant election. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enforce his pride, And his old hate unto you! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And presently, when you have drawn your number, Repair to the Capitol. CASSIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will so! TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will so! All Repent in their election! Cassius and Tamora lead the crowd. It is a terrifying spectacle of sudden mob rage, only a razor-thin edge to violence. Brutus and Sicinius watch, satisfied, like Robespierre an Saint Just looking over the bloody guillotine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus, dressed again in his familiar uniform, emerge from an antechamber with his comrade Titus. Menenius, General Cominius and several pro-Coriolanus Senators follow them. They stride down the corridor.
CORIOLANUS (TO TITUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tullus Aufidius then has assembled a new army? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has, my lord. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw you Aufidius? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is retired to Antium. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoke he of me? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did, my lord. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? What? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often he had met you, sword to sword; That of all things upon the earth he HATED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your person most. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Antium lives he? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Antium. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully. They hear the growing rumble of a crowd. Curious. They continue on and turn a corner to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The central lobby of the Senate is an open, airy space. Through the glass doors at the front of the lobby an unru crowd can be seen gathering. Police. Barricades. Sicinius and Brutus are waiting to intercept them.
CORIOLANUS (TO TITUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behold, these are the Tribunes of the people, The tongues of the common mouth. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass no further. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! What is that? BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be dangerous to go on. No further. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes this change? MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The matter? COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hath he not passed the nobles and the commons? BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cominius, no. Coriolanus steps closer to Brutus. The mob sees him throu the glass doors. The tension immediately increases. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I had children's voices? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tribunes, give way. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are incensed against him. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing to the growing CROWD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these your herd? MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be calm, be calm. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people cry you mocked them, and of late called them Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.
CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this was known before. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show too much of that For which the people stir. If you will PASS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To where you are bound, you must inquire your way. The crowd outside is growing restless, sensing and respon to the building tension. The police try to hold them back keeping them away from the doors. The crowd presses in. We see Cassius and Tamora at the forefront, urging the cr on. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's be calm-- COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are abused, set on-- MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, not now-- TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in this heat, sir-- Coriolanus strides angrily toward the doors and exits-- The others follow--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus launches himself into the crowd with blisterin ANGER: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nobler friends, I crave their pardons. For the mutable, rank-scented crowd, Let them regard me as I do not flatter, And therein behold themselves. I say again, In soothing them, we nourish against our SENATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition, Which we ourselves have ploughed for, sowed, and scattered, By mingling them with us!
MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no more! TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more words, we beseech you-- The mob has surrounded them all by now. The police are getting nervous, eyes darting uneasily fro the unruly crowd to the volatile men. This all has the potential of sparking to violence. We note a TV news crew moving into position, covering the action. Others film with cell phone cameras. We intercut of this footage. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Coriolanus, provoking) You speak of the people As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It were well we let the people know it. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were I as patient as the midnight sleep, By Jove, it would be my mind! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a mind That shall remain a poison where it is, Not poison any further. CORIOLANUS (EXPLODES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Shall remain"! Hear you this Triton of the minnows? Mark YOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His absolute "shall"? BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, should the people give One that speaks thus their voice? CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give my reasons, More worthier than their voices! Menenius tries to pull him away, Coriolanus shakes free a continues the attack:     51 CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Jove himself, It makes the consuls base; and my soul ACHES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To know, when two authorities are up, Neither supreme, how soon confusion, May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take The one by the other. The crowd roars angrily -- Coriolanus spins on them: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thus we debase the nature of our seats, and make the rabble Call our cares fears; which will in time Break ope the locks of the Senate, and BRING IN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crows to peck the eagles! MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, enough! BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough, with over-measure. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to the mob) He has spoken like a traitor, and shall ANSWER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As traitors do! At the word "traitor" Coriolanus loses all reason, he is FIRE: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou wretch, despite overwhelm thee! BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manifest treason! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a Consul? No! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hence, old goat! Coriolanus grabs Sicinius roughly and flings him aside-- At this -- the crowd ROARS in outrage -- the TV crews hus FOR POSITION--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius pulls Coriolanus off:
MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On both sides more respect! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to the crowd) Here's he that would take from you all your power! The crowd reacts angrily -- surging forward against the restraint of the police. We see grim RIOT POLICE marching into position. The crowd not intimidated, they are spoiling for a fight. The Tribunes provoke the crowd even more, escalating and building the fever: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are at point to lose your liberties! Martius would have all from you, Martius, Whom late you have named for Consul. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the city but the people?! TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True! The people are the city! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do here pronounce, upon the part of the people, Martius is worthy of present DEATH! A huge roar from the mob. Panic and violence building. Fa AND OVERLAPPING: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards, seize him! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll die here! BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay hands upon him! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: HELP, YE CITIZENS
dialogues.text: At his cue-- The civil violence threatened from the opening moments of this story finally EXPLODES--
With Cassius and Tamora in the forefront, the crowd attac THE POLICE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riot Police march in, slamming ahead with riot shields an TRUNCHEONS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mob fights back with anything at hand -- some are arm with clubs and knives, others snatch up garbage cans and newspaper vending machines, throwing them, smashing windo battling the police, kicking and punching and screaming-- It is civil disobedience. But it is also drunken, thug violence. Terrifying in its intensity-- Menenius gets Titus and Cominius to hustle Coriolanus awa MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, get you to your house! Be gone, away! All will be naught else-- COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, sir, along with us-- They hurry Coriolanus away-- The Riot Police, outnumbered, start firing TEAR GAS into CROWD-- SCREAMS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV news crew filming-- Chaotic, flurried violence-- Shaky TV images, cell phone video-- Choking, acrid gas-- It is a terrifying descent into public madness as all ord breaks down. Rome is bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius and the Tribunes are gathered in a darkened offi for some high-stakes politicking. Tamora, her face bloody from the riot, is with them. So t some supporters on either side.
MENENIUS (URGENTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I do know the Consul's worthiness, So can I name his faults-- SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consul! What Consul? MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Consul Coriolanus. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He Consul?! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is decreed He dies tonight. TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a disease that must be cut away. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, he's a limb that has but a disease: Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy. What has he done to Rome that's worth his death? Eh? Killing our enemies?! He sees that his words are having some effect, he presses POINT: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blood he hath lost -- He dropped it for his country. Some in the room murmur agreement. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll hear no more-- MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider this: he has been bred in the WARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since he could draw a sword, and is ill SCHOOLED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In graceful language Give me leave, I'll go to him, and undertake to bring HIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he shall answer by a lawful form, In peace, to his utmost peril. PRO-CORIOLANUS SENATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noble tribunes, It is the humane way.
ANOTHER SENATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other course Will prove too bloody, and the end of it Unknown to the beginning. Sicinius is about to retort when Brutus stops him. Brutus assents, assuming the voice of reason: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be you then as the people's officer. Menenius and Coriolanus' supporters are relieved. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you bring not Martius, we'll proceed In our first way. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring him to you. He goes quickly. Brutus turns to Sicinius and Tamora and begins to quietly explain his plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus strides angrily down a long corridor, in and o of shafts of light, seething to Titus: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them pull all about mine ears, PRESENT ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels, Yet will I still be thus to them--! TITUS MARTIUS-- CORIOLANUS (CONTINUING UNABATED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I muse my mother Does not approve me further! He slams through a door to the living room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stomps to confront his mother, who is currently conspiring with Menenius and a few Senators.
CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Volumnia, angrily) I talk of you! Why did you wish me milder? Would you HAVE ME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: False to my nature? Rather say I play The man I am! She is equally tough with him, not giving an inch, snappi RIGHT BACK: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, sir, sir, sir, I would have had you put your power well on, Before you had worn it out. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go! VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have been enough the man you are, With striving less to be so! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them hang! VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Av, and burn too! Her outraged fury matches his. Overpowers his. MENENIUS (TO CORIOLANUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough. You must return and mend it. Coriolanus turns away. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray, be counseled. I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of ANGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To better vantage. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well said, noble woman! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What must I do?
MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
