dialogues.text: Return to the Tribunes. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what then? What then? MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repent what you have spoke. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For them? I cannot do it to the gods. Must I then do it to them? VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are too absolute, Though therein you can never be too noble. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset, walking away) Why force you this? She pursues him: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that now it lies you on to speak To the people, not by your own instruction, Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you, But with such words that are but REHEARSED IN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tongue, though but bastards and SYLLABLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of no allowance to your bosom's truth... She moves closer to him. Her voice lower. A sort of seduction. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would dissemble with my nature where My fortunes and my friends at stake REQUIRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should do so in honor... She is very close now. Whispering. She touches him gently like a lover. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in this your wife, your son, These senators, the nobles And you. A long beat. All are silent, watching her spin her web.
VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prithee now, my son, Go and say to them Thou art their soldier, and being bred in BROILS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has not the soft way In asking their good loves; but thou wilt FRAME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This but done, even as she speaks, Why their hearts were yours. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prithee now, Go, and be ruled... (laughing to him) Although I know thou hadst rather Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf Than flatter him in a bower. Coriolanus smiles. A genuinely sweet moment between them. Cominius enters with several other political supporters. COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it is fit You make strong party, or defend yourself By calmness or by absence. All's in anger. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only fair speech. COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it will serve, if he Can thereto frame his spirit. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must -- and will. (TO CORIOLANUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prithee now, say you will, and go about it. CORIOLANUS MUST I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With base tongue give my noble heart A lie that it must bear? . Well, I will do it. But he is still agitated. Volumnia shares a concerned gla with Menenius.
CORIOLANUS (BITTERLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away, my disposition, and possess me Some harlot's spirit. A beggar's tongue Make motion through my lips, and my armed knees, Who bowed but in my stirrup, bend like HIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hath charity received! The thought of begging is too much, he rejects it, breaki AWAY: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not do it! Lest I cease to honor mine own truth And by my body's action teach my mind A most inherent baseness. Volumnia snarls at him, exasperated, building to a thunde that dwarfs his: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At thy choice, then! To beg of thee, it is my more dishonor Than thou of them. Come all to ruin! Let Thy mother rather feel thy pride than FEAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at DEATH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With as biq heart as thou! Do as you like! The words echo. It is as if he has been slapped. His resolve vanishes. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray, be content... Mother, I am going, chide me no more. He awaits her approval. She will not yet grant it. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I am going... Commend me to my wife. I'll return Consul, Or never trust to what my tongue can do In the way of flattery further. She graciously bows to him.
VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your will. Then she kisses him. And she goes. Like a queen. Volumnia triumphant. Always. Then a shocking hard cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded TV studio. The audience stands are filling up. Television cameras. Lights. Heavy security. On the stage: the set for a chat show. Translight of a ci skyline behind the set. Two standing microphones. At the side of the set, Sicinius and Brutus are conspirin with the two citizen activists, Cassius and Tamora: BRUTUS (TO SICINIUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this point charge him home: that he AFFECTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrannical power. If he evade us there, Enforce him with his envy to the people. SICINIUS (TO TAMORA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you a catalogue Of all the voices that we have procured Set down by the poll? TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have; it's ready. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the people hear me say "It shall be SO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the right and strength of the Commons," be it either For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them, If I say "Fine," cry "Fine!" - if "Death," cry "Death!" TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall inform them.     61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassius and Tamora hurry off to instruct and manipulate t crowd as best they can. They mix with the audience in the stands. MEANWHILE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gloomy but resolved Coriolanus walks with Cominius and Menenius between the tiers of audience, on the way to the set. COMINIUS ARM YOURSELF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To answer mildly, for they are prepared With accusations, as I hear, more strong Than are upon you yet. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word is "mildly." Pray you, let us go. Let them accuse me by invention, I Will answer in mine honor. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, but mildly. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly! Coriolanus steels himself as they emerge from between the stands and head toward the set. TV news crews are waiting. Blinding lights snap on. The crowd, on seeing Coriolanus, lets out a ROAR. Deafeni and savage. We see Cassius and Tamora moving through the crowd, instigating, convincing, imploring. Coriolanus ignores it all. Imperious to the end. Brutus and Sicinius wait on the set. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Sicinius) Put him to choler straight. Coriolanus and his supporters move to the stage. Coriolan glares at the Tribunes. The TV crews take up position. Menenius gestures for Coriolanus to step to the microphon whispering to him:
MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calmly, I do beseech you. Coriolanus steps to the microphone. Brutus gestures for the crowd to quiet down. We see bits of this scene through the monitors on the TV cameras. When the crowd is silent, Coriolanus begins to make a REHEARSED SPEECH: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honored gods-- But his voice echoes badly with reverb. Menenius adjusts microphone. Coriolanus begins again, quickly and by rote: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honored gods Keep Rome in safety, and the chairs of JUSTICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supplied with worthy men. Plant love among us. Throng our large temples with the shows of peace, And not our streets with war. COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, amen. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A noble wish. His boilerplate speech over, Coriolanus turns to Sicinius is at the other standing microphone: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I be charged no further than this present? Must all determine here? SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do demand, If you submit you to the people's voices. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia watches the proceedings closely on TV. She is pleased with her son's performance so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius, ever the People's Friend, steps to the micropho MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lo, citizens, he says he is content. The warlike service he has done, CONSIDER; THINK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon the wounds his body bears, which SHOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like graves in the holy churchyard. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable with this) Scratches with briers, Scars to move laughter only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius sits with several of his officers, leaning forwa watching the drama unfold on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider further, That when he speaks not like a citizen, You find him like a soldier. Do not take His rougher accents for malicious sounds, But, as I say, such as become a soldier. Coriolanus cuts in, his impatience getting the better of CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the matter That being passed for Consul with full voice, I am so dishonored that the very hour You take it off again? SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We charge you that you have contrived to TAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Rome all seasoned office, and to WIND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yourself into a power tyrannical (MORE)
SICINIUS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the coup de grace) For which you are a traitor to the people. Coriolanus responds, a cobra striking: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? Traitor?! MENENIUS (ALARMED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, temperately! Your promise. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fires in the lowest hell fold in the people! Call me their traitor, thou injurious Tribune! SICINIUS (CALLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark you this, people?! The crowd responds, egged on by Cassius and Tamora. A mur of voices, a chant growing, "Traitor traitor traitor..." Brutus cleverly plays the reasonable voice, knowing his w will further rile Coriolanus: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But since he hath Served well for Rome-- CORIOLANUS (SNAPS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you prate of service? BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talk of that, that know it. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?! I'll know no further. Let them pronounce death, exile, Flaying, pent to linger But with a grain a day - I would not buy Their mercy at the price of one fair word!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia watches, alarmed now. She knows this rage will p to be disastrous for her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sicinius seizes the moment to destroy Coriolanus, barking into the microphone: SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of the people And in the power of us the Tribunes, we, Even from this instant, banish him our city! In the people's name, I say IT SHALL BE SO! Well-rehearsed by Cassius and Tamora, many in the crowd respond with a fierce cry: CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It shall be so! It shall be so! Let him away! TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's banished! IT SHALL BE SO! CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It shall be so! It shall be so! It shall be so...! Cassius and Tamora keep the crowd at a fever pitch-- They keep chanting and railing-- A building seismic rumble-- COMINIUS (STEPPING FORWARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends--! SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sentenced. No more hearing. COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me speak! The crowd's fury is building-- It is all about to erupt--
BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no more to be said, but he is BANISHED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As enemy to the people and his country.

dialogues.speaker: IT SHALL BE SO
dialogues.text: CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It shall be so! It shall be so! It shall be so...! AND THEN-- CORIOLANUS EXPLODES--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His rage is volcanic-- He SLAMS the standing microphone away-- His dragon's ROAR silences the entire studio-- CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: YOU COMMON CRY OF CURS
dialogues.text: A collective intake of breath-- The crowd is stunned-- CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose breath I hate As reek of the rotten fens, whose loves I PRIZE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dead carcasses of unburied men That do corrupt my air... (each word an attack)

dialogues.speaker: I BANISH YOU
dialogues.text: The crowd is silent. No one dares to even breathe. AT THE VILLA: Volumnia watches, frozen, breathless. IN THE APARTMENT: Aufidius stands, riveted.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE STUDIO
dialogues.text: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here remain with your uncertainty. Let every feeble rumor shake your hearts! Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes, Fan you into despair! Have the power STILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To banish your defenders, till at length Your ignorance - which finds not till it feels, (MORE)
CORIOLANUS (CANT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making but reservation of yourselves; Still your own foes - deliver you As most abated captives to some nation That won you without blows! A beat. The TV cameras hum. The crowd is silent. Menenius and the others watch in amazement. Coriolanus slowly takes one last, long look at the people Rome. THEN: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despising, For you, the city, thus I turn my back. He turns and slowly walks toward one of the tunnels leadi from the studio. The crowd follows every step with their eyes. He stops. Turns back. Steel. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a world elsewhere. And he goes down the tunnel. Disappearing from view. A silent beat. Then, a chilling cry of absolutely Jacobin bloodlust from STANDS: TAMORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people's enemy is gone! The crowd SCREAMS their approval. The SAVAGE CRY echoes around the studio. The echoing roar takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outskirts of Rome are an urban wasteland. Abandoned factories. Rusting cars. Overgrown vacant lots. Collapsin advertising billboards. There is a lonely gas station in the distance, its neon s glowing a lurid green in the gray dawn light. We are at a Roman checkpoint on the highway into the city guardhouse and barrier. Some barbed wire barricades. Bore soldiers. Several cars pull up to the checkpoint. Two Roman securit SUVs. Menenius' familiar limousine. And Volumnia's enormo Bentley. Security Guards climb out of their vehicle, light cigaret and chat with the soldiers manning the checkpoint. Meneni Titus and Cominius climb from Menenius' limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, inside the Bentley, Coriolanus is comforting h wife and mother: CORIOLANUS (TO VIRGILIA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, leave your tears. A brief farewell. THE BEAST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With many heads butts me away. VIRGILIA 0 HEAVENS 0 HEAVENS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia has tears in her eyes as well. Coriolanus is surprisingly unsentimental and tough with her: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, mother, Where is your ancient courage? VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome, And occupations perish! CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, mother, I shall be loved when I am lacked. She nods to him, she has regained her composure.
Only then do they climb from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus takes his leave: CORIOLANUS (EMBRACING TITUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bid me farewell. TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farewell, Martius. CORIOLANUS (EMBRACING COMINIUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cominius, droop not, adieu. I'll do well yet. He goes to Menenius, who is genuinely distraught. For all political machinations, he truly cares for Coriolanus. Coriolanus is moved to see Menenius so emotional. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou old and true Menenius, Thy tears are salter than a younger man's, And venomous to thine eyes. MENENIUS (DEEPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could shake off but seven years I'd go with thee every foot. They embrace. Then Coriolanus knows it is time to go. He picks up a traveling bag and slings it over his shoulder. Looks back at his friends and family. A beat. A certain darkness creeps into his expression. An ominous resolve. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall hear from me still. He turns and looks to the distance. Miles and miles of wasteland and desolation.
His future. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go alone, Like to a lonely dragon. He strides off. The soldiers manning the checkpoint raise the barrier. Coriolanus walks under it. And begins walking down the lo highway away from Rome. The only sound is the cold, lonely moan of the wind. We fade to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus' exile. We see his long odyssey. It is a grueling physical journe and also something of a spiritual challenge. He is solita and without comfort: vulnerable to the elements and also the demons of his own psyche. We see him as... He walks along the barren highway. Trash piled along the road. A car zooms past. Whoosh. He is lost in dust... Blazing heat, like a furnace, as he trudges over desert terrain. Burning oil wells blacken the sky in the distanc Isolated, within himself, as he walks past the detritus o war a burned out tank a mountain of rusted artillery shells skeletons bleached in the sun... His clothes are dusty and dirty now. A sandstorm. He wrap scarf around his head, like a burnoose. Only his eyes vis now... A gypsy boy in tattered clothing riding a white horse pas him. The boy looks at him intently as he passes... We get a sense of him moving into different terrain, up i a mountain range, climbing... Then descending. Pouring rain. Lightning sparking. He is almost a Romantic figure now. Byronic. Wrapped in a cloak against the wildness of nature; the chiaroscuro flashes o light illuminating his haunted eyes...
We end at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus stands. Like a statue. All his life in his bla eyes. He is staring at a small town in the distance. We see a sign: ANTIUM. His destination since he began. The home of his nemesis, hated Aufidius. He begins to walk to the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, back in Rome, Brutus and Sicinius are having l at their usual hangout. They see Volumnia entering the restaurant, pulling Virgil after her. An ambush. She heads toward the Tribunes. Volumnia's eyes have the grim intensity of a predator. Sh looks strangely wild. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes his mother. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prepares to go) Let's not meet her. They say she's mad. Volumnia stalks up to them: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, you're well met. The hoarded plague of THE GODS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Requite your love! The Tribunes try to leave, she won't let them: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be gone? VIRGILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall stay too. I would I had the POWER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To say so to my husband. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mad?
VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, fool, is that a shame? Note but this, FOOL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hadst thou craft To banish him that struck more blows for ROME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than thou hast spoken words? SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to escape) 0 blessed heavens... Volumnia is creating a scene. Heads are turning. She continues her attack on Sicinius, but is distracted a JUMBLED: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More noble blows than ever thou wise words, And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what - YET GO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay -- but thou shalt stay too -- I would MY SON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him, His good sword in his hand. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then? VIRGILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then? He'd make an end of thy posterity. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastards and all. Menenius has entered the bar, seeing the trouble he goes them, tries to calm Volumnia: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, come, peace... BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray, let us go. He tries to leave the bar. Volumnia stops him for final attack, something like a curse in its power: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, pray, sir, get you gone. You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, HEAR THIS: (GRABS VIRGILIA) (MORE)
VOLUMNIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This lady's husband here, this, do you see?!-- Whom you have banished, does exceed you all. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, we'll leave you. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why stay we to be baited With one that wants her wits? VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would the gods had nothing else to do But to confirm my curses! Menenius gently restrains Volumnia and the Tribunes final escape the bar. Volumnia takes a breath, controls herself. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I meet 'em But once a day, it would unclog my heart Of what lies heavy to it. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have told them home; And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me? She turns to him. A cold and killing fire in her eyes. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anger's my meat. I sup upon myself, And so shall starve with feeding. She takes Virgilia's hand and drags her out. Menenius watches. Saddened. Once proud Volumnia, reduced to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antium is an old Volscian city gone to seed. It is Latin flavor, something like Havana. There is life to the place, a certain humid vitality. Som is singing in a bar. Old men are playing dominos on a pat Flickering TV and radio babel from terraced apartment buildings.

Coriolanus, his face still shrouded in the burnoose, like Hamas soldier, moves through the streets. He takes in the life of the town as he walks. Studying th faces of the Volscians around him. Coriolanus sees a heavily-guarded apartment building at t end of the street. Jeeps and SOLDIERS. Coriolanus approaches with stealth, moving in and out of shadows along the street, ducking into doorways and alley taking advantage of the darkness. He stops. Steps into the shadows. For he sees... Aufidius. Walking with a few of his officers. Aufidius is beloved in Antium. He has an easy manner with people. He stops and chats. Laughs with them. He dances f moment with a little girl. Coriolanus watches from the shadows, his expression compl There is real envy . Aufidius has such a comfortable way with the common people, he's natural, unaffected. Aufidius jokes with the little girl's parents for a momen and then moves on. Coriolanus watches Aufidius and his men go into an apartm building. He scans the building with the eye of a Special Forces soldier. He sees that the soldiers guarding the building bored, it is perfunctory work. Two YOUNG WOMEN, perhaps hookers, move past the front of building, flirting with the soldiers. The soldiers call a whistle to them, delighted. Coriolanus uses this distraction to slip into the shadows behind the soldiers and sneak into the building...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus moves again with stealth, heading toward what clearly the center of the action: a noisy room on the sec floor. The doorway is guarded by two serious GUARDS. These are n the bored soldiers out front, these are grim and intense warriors.
Coriolanus considers his course. Decides. Takes a breath. Focuses. He is like ice now. HE MOVES--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steady stride-- He walks right up to the Guards-- Before they can even respond-- He punches one HARD in the throat -- the Guard recoils, gasping for air-- Simultaneously, Coriolanus SLAMS his other hand violently over the entire face of the second Guard -- grabbing his firmly and SHOVING him back into the door-- So hard that the door slams aside-- And Coriolanus shoves the Guard into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius is having dinner with some of his men, their wiv and some children-- The soldiers bolt up, upsetting the table, smashing dishe pulling guns -- alarmed-- As Coriolanus powers in, still holding the second Guard b THE FACE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flings the Guard aside-- Aufidius and his men, all pointing weapons at Coriolanus, stunned. A long beat. Coriolanus' face is still masked by the burnoose. Only hi cold eyes are visible. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whence comes thou? What wouldst thou? Thy name? Coriolanus does not respond.
Aufidius is growing uneasy. His men are tense, ready to o fire at any second. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak, man! What's thy name? CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears, And harsh in sound to thine. The other Guard from outside, and several other soldiers, rush in. Weapons drawn, surrounding Coriolanus. He doesn't move a muscle. Aufidius, intrigued by the stranger's courage, waves his off. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what's thy name? Thou has a grim appearance .What's thy name? CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know'st thou me yet? AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know thee not Thy name? Finally, Coriolanus removes his burnoose. His face is exposed. The Volscians are stunned. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Caius Martius, who hath done To thee particularly and to all the VOLSCES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness MAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My surname Coriolanus. The Volscians look to Aufidius, very nervous, unsure how proceed. Aufidius just stares back at Coriolanus, stagger CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only that name remains. Aufidius doesn't understand. Coriolanus explains: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cruelty and envy of the people, Who have all forsook me, hath devoured the rest, And suffered me by the voice of slaves to BE (MORE)
CORIOLANUS (CANT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whooped out of Rome. Now this extremity Hath brought me to thy hearth, not out of HOPE -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistake me not - to save my life; for if I had feared death, of all the men in the WORLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have avoided thee, but in mere spite, To be full quit of those my banishers, Stand I before thee here. Coriolanus dares to take a step toward Aufidius-- The Volscians react. Guns are raised, fingers tight on triggers, an instant from opening fire-- Coriolanus carefully holds out his arms. He's unarmed. Aufidius nods to his men. They hold their fire. Coriolanus slowly crosses the room toward Aufidius. Step step. Their eyes are locked. Nothing else in the world exists. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will fight Against my cankered country with the SPLEEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of all the under fiends. But if thou Dares not this, then I present My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice... Coriolanus stops right in front of Aufidius and slowly, carefully, undoes his collar. Exposing his naked throat. Bending back his head. Ready for execution. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which not to cut would show thee but a fool, Since I have ever followed thee with hate, And cannot live but to thy shame unless It be to do thee service. A long beat. Aufidius stares at Coriolanus. The Volscians watch, eyes wide, too tense to do anything
Aufidius just continues to stare at Coriolanus. Eyes locked. Coriolanus blinks some sweat from his eyes. This tiny, hu response sparks something in Aufidius. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O Martius Martius Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart A root of ancient envy. He offers his hand. Coriolanus takes it. Aufidius continues to hold him by th hand, rather intensely, speaking low: AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me twine Mine arms about that body. He embraces Coriolanus. Aufidius' men finally relax. Weapons are lowered. Relieve glances exchanged. Some of the Volscians, though, are clearly suspicious of Coriolanus. They watch Aufidius and Coriolanus, concerned Aufidius still can't quite believe his ancient enemy is n his newest ally. AUFIDIUS KNOW THOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved the maid I married; never man Sighed truer breath. But that I see thee here, Thou noble thing, more dances my rapt HEART

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than when I first my wedded mistress saw Bestride my threshold. Coriolanus glances to him, perhaps a little disturbed or embarrassed by the intensity of Aufidius' words. Aufidius steps away from him, gestures for Coriolanus to AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thou Mars, I tell thee, We have a power on foot, and I had PURPOSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn, (MORE)
AUFIDIUS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or lose mine arm for it. Thou hast beat ME OUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve several times, and I have nightly SINCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me. Aufidius continues quietly, almost whispering: AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worthy Martius, Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that Thou art thence banished, we would muster ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From twelve to seventy, and, pouring war Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome, Like a bold flood, overbear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus sits, naked. He has finally washed off the lay of dirt from his journey. An old woman is using an electric razor to shave his head Aufidius is standing in the doorway to the room. Watching His eyes move over Coriolanus' body, adding up the scars wounds. A pause. Then Aufidius goes to the old woman. Takes the razor from her. She goes. Aufidius continues to shave Coriolanus' head himself. It is a deeply personal act, even intimate Yet Aufidius employs the same methodical rhythms as when he was sharpe his knife at the opening of the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volscian military command center. Maps, recon photos radio equipment. Stacks of grenade launchers and arms. Aufidius' CAPTAINS and AIDES wait alongside some bedraggl Volsce POLITICIANS in ill-fitting suits. Aufidius ushers Coriolanus in:
AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, come, go in, And take our friendly senators by the hands. Coriolanus shakes hands with the politicians: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bless me, gods. Then Aufidius takes him to a huge military map laid out o pool table. Rome and her territories. Strategic markers denote Roman forces and Volscian forces. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou WILT HAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leading of thine own revenges, take The one half of my commission. The Volscian soldiers and politicos are shocked. Aufidius giving Coriolanus command of half his forces! AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And set down--- As best thou art experienced, since thou KNOWS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thy country's strength and weakness--- thine own ways, Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, Or rudely visit them in parts remote, To fright them ere destroy. Aufidius looks at Coriolanus hard. There it is. The gaunt is thrown down. Coriolanus will have to completely betray Rome: expose her military weaknesses, tell her secrets. For all his neurotic intensity, Aufidius is a shrewd man. Coriolanus nods and turns to the battle map, moving vario markers around to show Rome's defensive positions. Aufidius watches him with Machiavellian calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several weeks later, back in Rome, politics go on as usua Menenius is passing the Tribunes' table. They josh with h BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Menenius?     81 SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tis he,'tis he! 0, he is grown most kind of late. Hail sir! MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hail to you both. SICINIUS YOUR CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is not much missed, but with his friends. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All's well, and might have been much BETTER IF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could have temporized. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he, hear you? MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, I hear nothing. His mother and his WIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear nothing from him. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caius Martius was A worthy officer in the war, but insolent, Overcome with pride, ambitious past all thinking, SELF-LOVING-- MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think not so. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Rome sits safe and still without him. They are distracted when people begin talking loudly, alarmed, at the bar. They hush each other and watch the T over the bar. Something has happened. On the TV: a SPECIAL REPORT. Breaking News. A scroll acro the bottom of the screen reads "The Volscians On The Marc TV ANCHORMAN (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reports the Volsces with two several POWERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are entered in the Roman territories, And with the deepest malice of the war Destroy what lies before them...
The whole bar is growing quiet now. All watching the TV, which shows grainy indistinct images -- like cell phone pictures -- of troops and tanks. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Martius' banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world. SICINIUS (NERVOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, what talk you of Martius? BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cannot be the Volsces dare break with us. TV ANCHORMAN (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the Senate House. Some news is COMING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That turns their countenances... (he listens to his ear piece for a second) Yes, the first report is seconded, and more, More fearful, is delivered. The TV picture switches to a flustered TV REPORTER outsid the Senate. A lot of nervous activity behind him. TV REPORTER (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is spoke freely out of many mouths - How probable I do not know - that Martius Has ioined with Aufidius-- There is an audible gasp in the bar -- quickly silenced a hushed so all can hear the TV: TV REPORTER (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --He leads a power against Rome, And vows revenge as spacious as between The youngest and oldest thing. Something close to terror on the faces of the politicos. Menenius, without a word, goes. He does not want to believe this is possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgilia lies on her bed. On the TV an imbedded WAR CORRESPONDENT is giving an upda intercut with shaky and unclear images of the Volscian ar on the move:

dialogues.speaker: TV WAR CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fearful army, led by Caius Martius Associated with Aufidius, rages Upon our territories, and have already Overborne their way, consumed with fire, AND TOOK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What lay before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia sits, almost frozen, smoking, watching the TV. H emotions are deep and dark. Her son, to her the model of all Roman virtues, has betra his country.

dialogues.speaker: TV WAR CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martius has joined with the Volscians - He is their god. He leads them like Boys pursuing summer butterflies Or butchers killing flies. Close up on Volumnia's face. She gives away practically nothing. She takes a slow drag on her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urban industrial wasteland. Old factories and abandoned warehouses. Broken asphalt. Smashed windows. The Volscians have set up camp here. On the decaying frin of the city. We see military hardware. Guns. Missile launchers. Armored vehicles. Soldiers are cleaning weapons, cooking meals, sleeping, playing video games. Then...

An incongruous sight... An old barber chair floats past. Moving across the blue s Carried overhead by a group of Volscian soldiers. But there is something different about these Volscian soldiers. They have altered their uniforms into something pagan and primitive. All have shaved heads. Many have fac tattoos or wear striking war paint. It is like something from LORD OF THE FLIES. They set the barber chair down outside an abandoned facto This shattered and abandoned factory is Coriolanus' domai It is decorated with human skulls. The CAMP BARBER, a fat man in a greasy butcher's apron, begins to strop his razor. Hard core young soldiers line up to have their heads shav They are Coriolanus' ACOLYTES. There is no sign of Coriolanus himself. Aufidius and his LIEUTENANT stand on the fringes, disturb by the strange cult of personality that has grown up arou Coriolanus. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they still fly to Coriolanus? LIEUTENANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know what witchcraft's in him, BUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your soldiers use him as the grace before meat, Their talk at table, and their thanks at end. And you are darkened in this action, sir. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bears himself more proud, Even to my person, than I thought he WOULD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When first I did embrace him. They turn and walk to the building where Aufidius is QUARTERED: LIEUTENANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I beseech you, think you he'll carry Rome?
AUFIDIUS (GRIM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he'll be to Rome As is the osprey to the fish, who takes IT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By sovereignty of nature. Aufidius nods to the guards outside his quarters and ente with his Lieutenant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shattered building. Old graffiti on the walls. Weapons. Maps. Aufidius' gear. Aufidius sits on his cot, deep in thought. He pulls a folded bit of paper from his pocket. Carefully lovingly unfolds it. He has been carrying this paper for months. We realize it is the glossy magazine cover with the pictu of Coriolanus that Aufidius tore out earlier. He gazes at the picture, his fingers smoothing the paper, tracing the contours of Coriolanus' face... AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether t'was pride, Whether defect of judgement, Or whether nature, Not to be other than one thing, Made him feared, So hated, and so banished. A beat as he studies the picture. His lieutenant watches him closely, disturbed by Aufidius obsession with Coriolanus. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So our virtues Lie in the interpretation of the time. He brings the picture closer, whispering now: AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One fire drives out one fire; one nail, ONE NAIL;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rights by rights founder, strengths by strengths do fail And when, Caius, Rome is thine, (MORE)
AUFIDIUS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou art poorest of all -- then shortly art thou mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rome is at war now, so the room is busy and tense. Maps a video footage chart the enemy's progress. Soldiers confer urgently outside the door. Menenius stands with the two Tribunes, Brutus and Siciniu With them are several SENATORS and GENERALS. Menenius snaps angrily: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll not go! SICINIUS (IMPLORING) GOOD MENENIUS-- MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, you that banished him! A mile before his tent fall down, and KNEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way into his mercy. They stop when Titus enters with General Cominius. Titus is dusty, has just come from somewhere. He is pale. Truly shaken. Menenius and the others crowd around him, waiting for his report. Titus sits, takes a moment to pull himself together, and reports with the grim severity of a death sentence: TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would not seem to know me. A beat. TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I urged our old acquaintance, and the DROPS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we have bled together. "Coriolanus" He would not answer to, forbade all names... A long beat. They wait for him to go on. Titus searches for the words to continue.
TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a kind of nothing. (a difficult beat) Titleless... Till he had forged himself a name in the FIRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of burning Rome. He has no more to say, his head drops. Menenius begins to leave the room. The Tribunes stop him, leading him to a secluded corner: SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you refuse your aid IN THIS-- BRUTUS IF YOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would be your country's pleader, your good tongue, More than the instant army we can make, Might stop our countryman. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll not meddle. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray you, go to him. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do? Brutus stops him, with real emotion: BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only make trial what your love can do For Rome towards Martius. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, and say that Martius Return me, as Titus is returned, Unheard - what then? SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet your good will Must have that thanks from Rome. Menenius thinks about it. BRUTUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the very road into his kindness, And cannot lose your way.
Menenius, despite all still a patriot at heart, decides. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll undertake it I think he'll hear me. The Tribunes are relieved. Cominius nods and escorts Mene out. Brutus and Sicinius return to Titus. TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll never hear him. SICINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? TITUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, he does sit in gold, his eye Red as it would burn Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Roman checkpoint on the desolate highway. A formidabl military presence here now: soldiers, heavy weapons, tank Volscian troops and a jeep can be seen down the highway. We see Menenius' limousine pull up. He and General Cominius climb out. Menenius is out of pla in his trim business suit: a politician among soldiers. Menenius steels himself then passes through the Roman checkpoint. He walks down the highway toward the distant Volscian tro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius is blindfolded, roughly pulled by two Volscian soldiers. We hear some of the soldiers hooting at him. We stay clos Menenius' blindfolded face, sharing his feeling of disorientation and suspense. The Volscians drag him into the abandoned factory--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally his guards stop him and pull off his blindfold-- REVEALING-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus. Transformed. And terrifying. He is no longer Roman. He is not Volscian. He is, as Titu said, "a kind of nothing." He sits in the barber chair. His head is completely shave His face is marked with martial face painting. These stri totemic markings also cover his scarred body. He is primitive. Inhuman. Like a dragon. The Angel of Death. His young warrior Acolytes -- similarly shaved and painte are gathered around him; his personal bodyguard and cult. A long beat as Menenius stares at his friend, stunned at pagan metamorphosis. Coriolanus just gazes back at him. Menenius finally pulls himself together and approaches, w FULSOME BRAVADO: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old friend Menenius does! 0 Martius, Martius! He steps forward to hug Coriolanus. Two of the Acolytes s him. He can approach no further. Menenius accepts this. No matter. He is completely confid he will be able to manipulate his protege. He always has the past. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou art preparing fire for us. Look thee, here's water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come to thee, but being assured none but myself could move thee, I have been blown out of your gates with sighs, and conjure thee to pardon Rome.
A long beat. Menenius waits for an answer. Grows uneasy. Then... CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away. MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? . Away? CORIOLANUS (ICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wife mother child I know not. MY AFFAIRS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are servanted to others. Menenius can't believe this cold response-- MENENIUS SIR-- CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore be gone. His frigid eyes slice into Menenius: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another word, Menenius, I will not hear thee speak. Menenius stares at him, shaken to the core. The Guards pull Menenius away. Coriolanus doesn't even glance at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the Roman checkpoint, Menenius strides toward his limousine. He has been deeply shaken by his interaction w the transformed Coriolanus. General Cominius follows urgently, Menenius doesn't stop: MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Martius is grown from man to dragon. He has wings; he's more than a creeping thing. He stops at his limo.
A beat. He turns back to Cominius. We see the pain in Menenius' e MENENIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no more mercy in him than there is milk in a male tiger. He climbs into his limo. Shuts the door. The limousine drives off, sending up a cloud of dust that swirls around Cominius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius sits in the back of his limo as it speeds back t Rome. The rejection by Coriolanus has wounded him. Also he is plagued by guilt. He helped create this monster. He pushe Coriolanus into politics. And now Coriolanus has lost his soul, even his humanity, and Rome is to be put to the swo All his fault. This preys on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Menenius' limousine pulls over by an isolated set of rail tracks. Weeds springing up. Battered advertising posters. old chain link fence. Menenius climbs out of the car and walks along the tracks Thinking. He stops. He sits on the railroad tracks. Pulls out a little pocket knife and, in the Roman fashion efficiently slits his wrists. He stares out over the hideous landscape. Blood begins to pool around his stylish shoes. From afar we see him, sitting on the railroad tracks, alo and forlorn in this surreal urban wasteland, like a Samue Beckett character. He slumps over.
Menenius is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red glow of dusk is shining through the cracked and d windows. Coriolanus, still in the barber chair, broods silently. Aufidius sits nearby, watching him. The visit from Menenius is troubling Coriolanus. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My partner in this action, You must report to the Volscian lords how PLAINLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have borne this business. Aufidius is curiously formal in his response, the estrangement he feels toward Coriolanus growing: AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only their ends You have respected; stopped your ears AGAINST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The general suit of Rome; never admitted A private whisper, no, not with such FRIENDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thought them sure of you. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This last old man, Whom with a cracked heart I have sent to Rome, Loved me above the measure of a father. Shouts and whistles from outside the factory draw their attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volumnia, Virgilia and Young Martius stride past the sold and mountains of military hardware. Volumnia leads, pulli the others by the hand. Some of the soldiers whistle. Some spit. Others laugh and make lascivious noises. Many just watch with grim dislike Volumnia appears to be completely impervious to the whist and cruel taunts. Her head is high, back straight, eagle forward. She was never more a Roman patrician.
She is magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus stands as Volumnia, Virgilia and Young Martius led into the factory. He tries to register nothing, assuming a sort of glacial calm. Volumnia and the others stop -- taking in Coriolanus' sav new demeanor and appearance -- taking in the Acolytes and pagan totems. Volumnia just stands, peering sternly at her son. As if daring him not to crumble before her. He doesn't. Aufidius watches everything closely. It is Virgilia, finally, who bravely approaches: VIRGILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord and husband-- He stop her, almost a warning, with: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome. VIRGILIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sorrow that delivers us thus changed Makes you think so. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best of my flesh, Forgive my tyranny, but do not say For that "Forgive our Romans." She shows great courage. Stepping forward and kissing him deeply. A long kiss. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, a kiss Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge. It is a perverse response. In his monomaniacal imaginatio his wife's kiss is obsessively equated with his revenge o Rome. He finally moves to Volumnia, simply can't resist her orb pull.
CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gods I prate, And the most noble mother of the world Leave unsaluted. Sink, my knee, in the earth. He kneels before her. It is done with a sense of duty and protocol, not affection. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, stand up blest. He rises. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then with no softer cushion than the FLINT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kneel before thee. She quickly and dramatically kneels before him. It is a c de theatre and a masterpiece of manipulation. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Your knees to me? To your corrected son? VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou art my warrior; I hope to frame thee. She indicates Young Martius: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a poor epitome of yours, Which by the interpretation of full time May show like all yourself. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his son) The god of soldiers, Inform thy thoughts with nobleness, that thou may prove To shame invulnerable. Volumnia pulls Young Martius down: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your knee, sir. She pulls Virgilia down: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even he, your wife, and myself, Are suitors to you.
All three kneel before Coriolanus. A pitiable sight. But has no pity. He turns, sits in the barber chair. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beseech you, peace! Or, if you'd ask, remember this: Do not bid me dismiss my soldiers, or CAPITULATE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again with Rome's mechanics. Tell me not Wherein I seem unnatural. Desire not To ally my rages and revenges with Your colder reasons. Volumnia stands, assuming again a position of strength. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0, no more, no more! You have said you will not grant us anything, For we have nothing else to ask but that Which you deny already; yet we will ask, That, if you fail in our request, the BLAME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May hang upon your hardness. Therefore hear us. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for WE'LL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear naught from Rome in private. (coldly, to her) Your request? VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we be silent and not speak, our RAIMENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And state of bodies would reveal what LIFE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have led since thy exile. Think with THYSELF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How more unfortunate than all living WOMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we come hither, since that thy sight, WHICH SHOULD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance with comforts, Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow, Making the mother, wife, and child to see The son, the husband and the father TEARING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His country's bowels out.
Coriolanus' face is a study in aloof neutrality. Yet he i listening intensely and Volumnia's words are affecting. She fights back emotion. It is impossible to tell if this real or feigned. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For myself, son, I propose not to wait on fortune till These wars determine. If I cannot PERSUADE THEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather to show a noble grace, thou shalt NO SOONER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March to assault thy country than to Tread on thy mother's womb That brought thee to this world. VIRGILIA (STANDS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, and mine, That brought you forth this boy, to keep YOUR NAME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living to time. Young Martius stands as well and approaches his father, challenging and warlike: YOUNG MARTIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall not tread on me. I'll run away till I am bigger, but then I'll fight! Coriolanus stares at him -- the intensity of the boy's aggression is disturbing. And familiar. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have sat too long. He rises and turns as if to go-- VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay, go not from us thus! Her command stops him. She appeals, quickly getting to th point of her argument: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were so that our request did tend To save the Romans, thereby to destroy The Volsces whom you serve, you might CONDEMN US

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As poisonous of your honor. No, our suit Is that you reconcile them -- so the VOLSCES (MORE)
VOLUMNIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May say "This mercy we have showed," the Romans, "This we received," and each in either SIDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give the all-hail to thee and cry, "Be BLEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For making up this peace!" Coriolanus does not respond. She softens... VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak to me, son... Still he does not respond. His emotions are roiling. Still she is soft and vulnerable... VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why dost not speak? But softness is not a note she plays naturally. She knows Her natural aggressiveness comes out, anger and outrage gradually boiling to the surface: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinks thou it honorable for a noble man Still to remember wrongs? Daughter, speak you. He cares not for your weeping. Speak thou, boy. Perhaps thy childishness will move him MORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than can our reasons. There's no man in THE WORLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More bound to his mother, yet here he lets me prate Like one in the stocks! She is assaulting him now, on the attack: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thou hast never in thy life Showed thy dear mother any courtesy, When she, poor hen, Has clucked thee to the wars and safely HOME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loaded with honor. Say my request's unjust, And spurn me back; and the gods will (MORE)
VOLUMNIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: plague thee, That thou restrains from me the duty WHICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a mother's part belongs! Coriolanus can take no more, turns and begins to walk awa Volumnia reacts like lightning -- grabbing Virgilia and Y Martius and dragging them to the dirt with her-- VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down! Let us shame him with our knees! She claws at the dirt -- like Hecuba -- keening -- a shoc explosion of raw emotion -- almost an incantation: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down! An end! This is the last. So we will home to Rome, And die among our neighbors. Nay, behold! This boy, that cannot tell what he would HAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But kneels and holds up hands for fellowship, Does reason our petition with more STRENGTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Than thou hast to deny it. She remains kneeling, panting for air. Coriolanus looks at her. His noble mother. Clawing in the dirt like an animal. Filthy. Despairing. Her face wet wit tears. She looks back up at him. She senses she has failed. It's over. VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, let us go. She rises slowly, her age showing. Her spirit broken. Or seeming so. She stares at Coriolanus as she rips off the Roman Eagle medal she wears and flings it to the ground. The blood red sky of sunset behind her reflects her passi as she summons up all her strength for a lacerating and i FAREWELL: VOLUMNIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fellow had a Volscian to his mother; His wife is in Corioles and his child (MORE)
VOLUMNIA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like him by chance Yet give us our dispatch. I am hushed until our city be afire, And then I'll speak a little. She turns and begins to go. But... We see finally Coriolanus crack. Like a great building crumbling. Like fissures cutting across marble. Emotion floods into him. He lunges forward and grabs her hand. Volumnia stops. Time stands still. He doesn't speak. THEN: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O mother mother... What have you done? He falls to his knees, clutching her hand. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behold, the heavens do ope, The gods look down -- and this unnatural SCENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh at. He buries his head in her, like a lost child: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O my mother, mother! 0! You have won a happy victory for Rome; But for your son - believe it, 0 believe it! - Most dangerously you have with him PREVAILED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he looks up at her DEEPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If not most mortal to him. She looks down at him. His meaning, his foreshadowing, is clear: she has saved Rome, but he knows he is doomed. Rom will live. He will die. This is the price for her victory today.
She is willing to pay that price. So is he. A moment between them. He accepts his destiny. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But let it come. He stands, regains his composure. He slowly walks to Aufidius. He leans close, speaking intimately: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aufidius, though I cannot make true wars, I'll frame convenient peace. Now, good Aufidius, Were you in my stead, would you have HEARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mother less? Or granted less? Aufidius? AUFIDIUS (CAREFULLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was moved withal. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dare be sworn you were. And, sir, it is no little thing to make Mine eyes to sweat compassion. But, good sir, What peace you'll make, advise me. We study Aufidius' face. He gives away nothing. Coriolanus turns back to Volumnia. Looks at her. She is victorious. The crimson sky looms over her ominously. And we go to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A solemn peace treaty signing ceremony. Coriolanus represents the Volscians. Cominius represents Romans. They sit side-by-side at desks signing the treaty Volumnia and Virgilia, gorgeously dressed, are present. S too Brutus and Sicinius. The press films everything.     101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has the stiff formality of a White House ceremony. Cominius concludes signing: COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A merrier day did never yet greet Rome, No, not the expulsion of the Tarquins. We have all Great cause to give great thanks. He looks to Volumnia. COMINIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behold our patroness, the life of Rome. She is erect and exalted. "The Life of Rome" personified. She ignores her son. Coriolanus will not look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rundown Truck Stop in an industrial wasteland. Garish, buzzing neon. Filthy 18-wheelers refueling. Music droning from a radio. Aufidius, his Lieutenant and seven of his men are waiting outside the dusty diner. The men with Aufidius are thugs and killers, the most bru Volsces he could find. We note a couple of Coriolanus' Acolytes among them. They have turned with great venom on their hero. They are like a mafia hit squad, waiting for Coriolanus t return with the peace treaty. Aufidius is deep in thought. His Lieutenant breaks the silence: LIEUTENANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it with our general? AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As with a man by his own charity slain. LIEUTENANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our soldiers will remain uncertain whilst 'Twixt you there's difference; but the (MORE)
LIEUTENANT (CANT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fall of either Makes the survivor heir of all. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it, And my pretext to strike at him admits A good construction. A beat. He continues more to himself than them, almost convincing himself. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I raised him, and I pawned Mine honor for his truth; who being so heightened, He watered his new plants with dews of flattery, Seducing so my friends. (BITTERLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the last I seemed his follower, not partner, and He waged me with his countenance as if I had been mercenary. LIEUTENANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he did, my lord. The army marveled at it; and in the last, When he had carried Rome and that we LOOKED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For no less spoil than glory-- Aufidius works himself into an intense, neurotic rage: AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was it! For which my sinews shall be stretched upon him. At a few drops of women's rheum, which ARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As cheap as lies, he sold the blood and LABOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of our great action -- Therefore shall he die, And I'll renew me in his fall. LIEUTENANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, at your vantage, Ere he express himself or move the people With what he would say, let him feel your sword, Which we will second.
AUFIDIUS (SEES SOMETHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say no more. In the distance they can see a Roman military truck approaching. Clouds of dust billow up. They exchange a look. This is what they have been waiting for. They stand, stretch and prepare. The truck stops across the highway from them and Coriolan gets out. He holds a copy of the peace treaty in a leathe portfolio. He is unarmed. He stops. He sees Aufidius and the thugs. Waiting for him. Like a d squad. Coriolanus looks at them. He knows exactly what's going to happen. He is ready. He nods and the truck drives off. Coriolanus slowly crosses the highway to the truck stop, a gunslinger walking down Main Street. There is something new to Coriolanus here. A sort of acceptance. He knows his time is past. Aufidius and the thugs go to meet him. The thugs spread o bit, strategically, getting ready to strike. Coriolanus' experienced eyes miss none of this. They meet in the parking lot. CORIOLANUS (TO AUFIDIUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am returned your soldier, No more infected with my country's love Than when I parted hence, but still SUBSISTING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under your great command. He hands the treaty portfolio to Aufidius: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have made peace With no less honor to the Volscians Than shame to the Romans.
AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing the treaty to LIEUTENANT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it not, But tell the traitor, in the highest DEGREE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hath abused your powers. Coriolanus is ready for Aufidius' ploy. He is amused at t obvious attempt to anger him: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitor? How now? AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, traitor, Martius. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Martius"? AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, Martius, Caius Martius! Dost thou THINK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll grace thee with that robbery, thy STOLEN NAME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Coriolanus"? He spins to the others, making the case against Coriolanu with cutting bitterness: AUFIDIUS PERFIDIOUSLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has betrayed your business and given up, For certain drops of salt, your city Rome- I say "your city" - to his wife and MOTHER;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaking his oath and resolution, like A twist of rotten silk; never admitting Counsel of the war, but at his nurse's TEARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whined and roared away YOUR VICTORY! Coriolanus tries to contain his anger: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear'st thou, Mars? AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name not the god, thou boy of tears.
CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Measureless liar, thou has made my heart Too great for what contains it. "Boy"? 0 slave. Coriolanus' eyes miss nothing a Volscian thug shifting a bead of sweat on another one secretly reaching into his coat for a weapon. Some of the Volscian thugs are clearly nervous. Coriolanus is ready. He prepares himself mentally to die. is acutely controlled: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut me to pieces, Volsces. Men and lads, stain all your edges on me. It is a dare. A challenge. CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Boy"? False hound. If you have writ your annals true, 'tis THERE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, like an eagle in a dovecote, I Fluttered your Volscians in Corioles. His gaze burns into Aufidius: CORIOLANUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone I did it "Boy." AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him die for it. At this command, his men move-- Aufidius steps back as-- The Volscian thugs attack-- With knives, machetes and tire irons-- Coriolanus fights bravely -- disarming two, grabbing thei weapons, killing them, fighting back-- Slashing and cutting his way through the killers- Closer and closer to Aufidius, who just watches-- Blood spattering and spraying- But the thugs overpower Coriolanus, there are just too ma

They stab him -- slicing with knives -- battering with ch and clubs -- finally emptying pistols him into him-- It is graceless and brutal carnage. Slaughter. But still he comes on. Body riddled with bullets and cut bits. He refuses to fall. Like something immortal. An obs demon of blood. Finally the thugs move away. Coriolanus still stands. Teetering. His face is a swollen mask of blood and gore. Blood flows from his body, poolin around his feet, spreading across the parking lot. Aufidius steps forward. What is left of Coriolanus glares at him through blood. Aufidius slowly pulls his knife. The same knife he was sharpening so carefully at the opening of the story. It h finally found its purpose. Coriolanus looks at him. Then slowly Coriolanus tries to raise one bleeding arm this requires superhuman effort his slashed fingers clutch his shirt he rips it open exposing his breast. Ready. He locks eyes with Aufidius. Aufidius steps to him. Takes his neck. Pulls him onto the knife. Driving it into him. Cradling his head like a love They stand like this. Then Coriolanus falls. A pause. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him up. No one moves. AUFIDIUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assist. Abrupt cut to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coriolanus' body is awkwardly tossed into the back of an truck. Like a sack of potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of Volscians are gathered around the back of the truck. They have come to see Coriolanus' body. We watch their faces. Normal people. A range of grim emot One raises a cell phone. Takes a photo. More phone cameras come out. Streaming video. Recording t moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the TV: The footage from the cell phone video. Coriolanus' body in the back of the trunk. Volumnia stands. Looking at her son. His body sprawled ungainly in death. No ritual or ceremony. No honor. Her face. Snap to black. The End.
